intro: Aeluropus mesopotamicus, commonly known as the Mesopotamian saltgrass, is a perennial grass species native to arid and semi-arid regions of the Middle East and Central Asia. It is characterized by its low-growing, tufted habit and narrow, grass-like leaves that are adapted to withstand saline and drought conditions. The plant produces small, spikelet-based inflorescences, which are typical of the Poaceae family. It thrives in saline soils and is often found in coastal and inland salt marshes. Aeluropus mesopotamicus plays a vital role in stabilizing soil and providing habitat for various wildlife in its native environment.
